block.p: MURRAY CHASS examines the strengths and weaknesses of the National League.
East
PROJECTED FINISH 1. METS 2. BRAVES 3. PHILLIES 4. MARLINS 5. NATIONALS

The rule of thumb for picking the National League East winner was postulated here a year ago: Do not pick against the Atlanta Braves as long as they are defending their title. They did not finish in first place last season, so feel free to look elsewhere for a winner this year.
MURRAY CHASS examines the strengths and weaknesses of the National League.
East
PROJECTED FINISH 1. METS 2. BRAVES 3. PHILLIES 4. MARLINS 5. NATIONALS

The rule of thumb for picking the National League East winner was postulated here a year ago: Do not pick against the Atlanta Braves as long as they are defending their title. They did not finish in first place last season, so feel free to look elsewhere for a winner this year.

If you believe Jimmy Rollins, you will pick Philadelphia. Rollins, the Phillies' shortstop, said that the Phillies were the team to beat. It's doubtful that even Phillies fans believe that. General Manager Pat Gillick said he didn't.

What about the Braves? They have presumably fixed their most glaring problem of last season, their bullpen, and they have some good young players who have sufficient offense. Hmmm. Interesting thought.

But it's hard to overlook the defending champion Mets, even with their pitching problems. The Mets fell a game short of reaching the World Series last year in part because of pitching injuries, and some of those problems persist.

Pedro Martínez, recovering from a torn rotator cuff, remains unavailable until sometime in the second half of the season; Orlando Hernández seems to incur an injury every once in awhile; and Duaner Sánchez, who was an outstanding reliever the first half of last season, has a broken bone in his shoulder that could keep him out until at least August.

A succession of veteran pitchers (Chan Ho Park, Aaron Sele, Jorge Sosa) failed to win starting jobs in spring training, making it easy and necessary for Manager Willie Randolph to write in the names John Maine, Oliver Pérez and the rookie Mike Pelfrey to go with the 41-year-olds Tom Glavine and Hernández.

Is this any way to win a division title? It's going to have to be, because it says here the Mets should win again. They should win with a glittering lineup that produced one of the highest-scoring offenses in the league last year. If Shawn Green (.257 in 34 Mets games) rediscovers his hitting ability, the offense will be even better.

The Atlanta Braves scored 15 more runs than the Mets, so they should not be regarded lightly. With the addition of Rafael Soriano and Mike Gonzalez to work in the bullpen with Bob Wickman, the Braves will be dangerous.

If the new, young right side of the infield, Scott Thorman and Kelly Johnson, hits like Jeff Francoeur and Brian McCann, two even younger players who made impressive debuts two years ago, more danger would lurk in the Braves' dugout.

The Philadelphia Phillies are not to be ignored, not with Ryan Howard (league-leading 58 homers and 149 runs batted in, to go with a .313 average) and Chase Utley (32, 102, .309). But Howard will get the Barry Bonds treatment -- walk after walk after walk -- and will have to practice patience to avoid those pitching traps.

When Rollins offered his proclamation, he did so because he was optimistic about the team's new pitchers. He was elated by the addition of two starters, Freddy García (17-9 with the White Sox) and Adam Eaton (7-4 in 13 starts with Texas). The Phillies already had Jamie Moyer, 44, from a trade late last season.
On second thought, maybe Rollins is just an excitable kind of guy.

The Florida Marlins became excited about their team last year, winning 78 games despite a major-league-low $15 million payroll, but then they fired Manager Joe Girardi. Now it's up to Fredi González to continue the job Girardi began.

He will do it with basically the same team Girardi had. The Marlins' payroll may rise because their players will be earning slightly more than they did last year, when many of them were rookies, but the Marlins added almost no one. On the other hand, they lost their closer, Joe Borowski (36 saves), and replaced him with Jorge Julio (16 saves).

The Washington Nationals lost two hitters, Alfonso Soriano (46 homers, 41 stolen bases) and José Vidro (.289), and two of their starting pitchers, Ramón Ortiz (11-16) and Tony Armas Jr. (9-12), and did not acquire anyone of substance.
That will not make Manny Acta's first managing job any easier as he replaces Frank Robinson, the team's manager for five years.

A rookie, Kory Casto, will be among those trying to replace Soriano in left field. Felipe López, acquired from Cincinnati last season, is the second baseman. New starting pitchers? The Nationals' five starters made a total of 36 starts in the majors last season.
HEAVY HITTERS
Scoring was no problem for the Phillies (865 runs), Braves (849) and Mets (834) last year; they were the top three teams in the league. CHASE UTLEY led the N.L. in runs.
METS 2006: 97-65, first place

PROBABLE STARTERS 1B Carlos Delgado 2B José Valentín SS José Reyes 3B David Wright LF Moises Alou CF Carlos Beltrán RF Shawn Green C Paul Lo Duca SP Tom Glavine Pedro Martínez (d.l.) Orlando Hernández John Maine Oliver Pérez Mike Pelfrey* Closer Billy Wagner
ATLANTA BRAVES 2006: 79-83, third

PROBABLE STARTERS 1B S. Thorman/C. Wilson 2B Kelly Johnson SS Édgar Rentería 3B Chipper Jones LF R. Langerhans/M. Diaz CF Andruw Jones RF Jeff Francoeur C Brian McCann SP John Smoltz Tim Hudson Chuck James Lance Cormier Mark Redman Mike Hampton (d.l.) Closer Bob Wickman
PHILADELPHIA PHILLIES 2006: 85-77, second

PROBABLE STARTERS 1B Ryan Howard 2B Chase Utley SS Jimmy Rollins 3B Wes Helms LF Pat Burrell CF Aaron Rowand RF Shane Victorino C Rod Barajas SP Brett Myers Cole Hamels Freddy García Adam Eaton Jamie Moyer Closer Tom Gordon
FLORIDA MARLINS 2006: 78-84, fourth

PROBABLE STARTERS 1B Mike Jacobs 2B Dan Uggla SS Hanley Ramírez 3B Miguel Cabrera LF Josh Willingham CF Alejandro De Aza* RF Joe Borchard Jeremy Hermida (d.l.) C Miguel Olivo SP Dontrelle Willis Aníbel Sánchez Scott Olsen Ricky Nolasco Sergio Mitre Closer Jorge Julio
WASHINGTON NATIONALS 2006: 71-91, fifth

PROBABLE STARTERS 1B Dmitri Young Nick Johnson (d.l.) 2B Felipe López SS Cristian Guzmán 3B Ryan Zimmerman LF Ryan Church/Kory Casto* CF Nook Logan RF Austin Kearns C Brian Schneider SP John Patterson Jerome Williams Matt Chico Jason Bergmann Shawn Hill Closer Chad Cordero *-Rookie
Central
PROJECTED FINISH 1. CARDINALS 2. BREWERS 3. ASTROS 4. CUBS 5. PIRATES 6. REDS

For a team that was supposed to be the next World Series champion, the Chicago Cubs were embarrassingly bad last year. Instead of following the Red Sox and the White Sox as champions after long droughts, the Cubs created the league's worst record.
How embarrassed were the Cubs? They were so embarrassed they spent as they had never spent before. Start with $136 million for Alfonso Soriano and go from there.

The Cubs, a fiscally conservative organization, signed Soriano, a second baseman turned left fielder, and pronounced him their center fielder. They signed Mark DeRosa to play second base. They signed Cliff Floyd to share playing time in left field. They signed Ted Lilly and Jason Marquis to be their Nos. 2 and 3 starting pitchers, giving Lilly an eyebrow-raising $10 million a year.

That's $10 million a year for a pitcher with a 59-58 career record who has never won more than two games more than he lost in a season. Marquis got only $7 million a year for his 56-52 record, though he has a winning record only once in six full seasons. He pitched so poorly last season (14-16, 6.02 earned run average) that he was left off the St. Louis Cardinals' World Series roster.
The Cubs have become a managers' graveyard, and Dusty Baker was the latest to be buried at Wrigley Field. Lou Piniella began whistling as soon as he was named the new manager.
At the opposite end of the division from the Cubs, the St. Louis Cardinals won only 83 games, but they also won the World Series.

The Cardinals will try to do it again with a revamped rotation. Jeff Suppan, Jeff Weaver and Marquis are gone. Mark Mulder is recovering from shoulder surgery and will miss a good portion of the season. Chris Carpenter and Anthony Reyes are the holdovers, Kip Wells (1-5, 6.69) is a newcomer via free agency and Adam Wainwright and Braden Looper are recruits from the bullpen.
Wainwright was the postseason closer last season after Jason Isringhausen had hip surgery, and Looper has never started a game in 572 major league appearances.

Roger Clemens has started 690 games, 84 for the Houston Astros the past three years. But while the Astros await their Clemens fix this year, they may figure out how to score more runs. Their inability to score cost them a spot in the playoffs last year.

They spent $100 million for Carlos Lee's potent bat. Last year Lee had career highs of 37 home runs and 116 runs batted in, making it the fourth successive season he had hit more than 30 homers. The Astros also added infielder Mark Loretta, who has a .299 career batting average and hit .424 in 21 games for Houston in 2002.
The Cincinnati Reds were the division's biggest surprise last year, standing only a percentage point from first place Aug. 24 before slipping and finishing three and a half games from the top.

They have already sprung their surprise this year. They have moved Ken Griffey Jr. to right field and put Ryan Freel in center. Griffey, who was 19 years old when he began playing in the majors and has somehow become 37, has just finished recovering from a broken wrist, his eighth serious injury since he joined the Reds in 2000.

The Milwaukee Brewers could use surprises for their offense, defense and pitching. They were in the lower strata in all three phases last year, which explains why they dropped back under .500 (75-87) after finishing at .500 following 12 consecutive losing seasons.

They traded one of their best pitchers, Doug Davis, for a good-hitting catcher, Johnny Estrada (.302), and signed Suppan to replace Davis. They have also moved Bill Hall, their best run producer (35 homers, 85 R.B.I.), to center field from shortstop.
While the Brewers are no longer burdened by a long streak of consecutive losing seasons, the Pittsburgh Pirates enter the season with their streak intact at 14.

But the Pirates think they are on the right track. They finished last season with a 37-35 record in their last 72 games after a 30-60 start, and they had a 16-6 record in their last 22 one-run games after being 8-25 in their first 33.

One of their biggest problems was a lack of a strong left-handed hitter, and they may have corrected it with the acquisition of first baseman Adam LaRoche, who hit 32 homers and drove in 90 runs for the Braves last season.
A DROUGHT IN PITTSBURGH
After winning three straight division titles from 1990 to '92, the Pirates have had 14 consecutive losing seasons. JASON BAY has been a bright spot with 30-homer seasons in 2005 and 2006.
ST. LOUIS CARDINALS 2006: 83-78, first

PROBABLE STARTERS 1B Albert Pujols 2B Adam Kennedy SS David Eckstein 3B Scott Rolen LF Chris Duncan CF Jim Edmonds RF Spiezio/Taguchi/Wilson Juan Encarnación (d.l.) C Yadier Molina SP Chris Carpenter Kip Wells Adam Wainwright Anthony Reyes Braden Looper Mark Mulder (d.l.) Closer Jason Isringhausen
MILWAUKEE BREWERS 2006: 75-87, fourth

PROBABLE STARTERS 1B Prince Fielder 2B Rickie Weeks SS J. J. Hardy 3B Counsell/Graffanino Corey Koskie (d.l.) LF G. Jenkins/K. Mench CF Bill Hall RF Corey Hart C Johnny Estrada SP Chris Capuano Ben Sheets Jeff Suppan Dave Bush Claudio Vargas Closer Francisco Cordero
HOUSTON ASTROS 2006: 82-80, second

PROBABLE STARTERS 1B Lance Berkman 2B Craig Biggio SS Adam Everett 3B Morgan Ensberg LF Carlos Lee CF Chris Burke RF Jason Lane/Luke Scott C Brad Ausmus SP Roy Oswalt Jason Jennings Woody Williams Wandy Rodríguez Fernando Nieve Closer Brad Lidge
CHICAGO CUBS 2006: 66-96, sixth

PROBABLE STARTERS 1B Derrek Lee 2B Mark DeRosa SS César Izturis 3B Aramis Ramírez LF Matt Murton/Cliff Floyd CF Alfonso Soriano RF Jacque Jones C Michael Barrett SP Carlos Zambrano Ted Lilly Jason Marquis Rich Hill Wade Miller Closer Ryan Dempster
PITTSBURGH PIRATES 2006: 67-95, fifth

PROBABLE STARTERS 1B Adam LaRoche 2B Freddy Sanchez SS Jack Wilson 3B José Bautista LF Jason Bay CF Chris Duffy RF Xavier Nady C Ronny Paulino SP Zach Duke Ian Snell Paul Maholm Tom Gorzelanny Tony Armas Jr. Closer Salomón Torres
CINCINNATI REDS 2006: 80-82, third

PROBABLE STARTERS 1B Scott Hatteberg 2B Brandon Phillips SS Álex González 3B Edwin Encarnación LF Adam Dunn CF Ryan Freel RF Ken Griffey Jr. C David Ross SP Aaron Harang Bronson Arroyo Eric Milton Kyle Lohse Matt Belisle Closer Dustin Hermanson *-Rookie
West
PROJECTED FINISH 1. DODGERS 2. PADRES 3. GIANTS 4. DIAMONDBACKS 5. ROCKIES
For this division, off-season activity seemed to be a ceaseless whirlwind of activity, a spirited game of ''Can You Top This?''

San Diego signs Greg Maddux away from Los Angeles, Los Angeles signs Jason Schmidt away from San Francisco and Randy Wolf away from Philadelphia, San Francisco signs Barry Zito -- for a whopping $126 million, no less. And before the pitching merry-go-round stops, Arizona trades for Randy Johnson and Doug Davis.

Los Angeles re-signs Nomar Garciaparra and signs Juan Pierre. San Francisco signs Dave Roberts and Bengie Molina. San Diego signs Marcus Giles. And throughout all this, San Francisco re-signs Barry Bonds and re-signs him and re-signs him.
And to add a special touch to the frenetic activity, the Giants snatch Bruce Bochy from San Diego to manage them after he had managed the Padres for a dozen years.
None of the teams called a timeout, but at some point everyone gave in to exhaustion and prepared for spring training. Will anyone have anything left for the season?

Among all the moves, the strangest was Bochy's. Not only had he spent his entire major league managerial career in San Diego, but he had also managed the Padres to the division title the past two seasons and had a long, close relationship with the Padres' general manager, Kevin Towers, who was his minor league teammate.

His relationship with Towers, however, could not withstand the desire of Sandy Alderson, the team's chief executive, to make a change when Bochy's contract was up. Knowing an extension was not on the horizon, Bochy jumped.
Now Bud Black, a hotly pursued candidate in recent years, is the rookie manager of the San Diego Padres, who have lost six of seven playoff games against the Cardinals the past two Octobers.

They have made changes in search of a new outcome. Giles, the younger brother of Padres right fielder Brian Giles, is at second base instead of Josh Barfield; Kevin Kouzmanoff, a rookie with home run potential, is at third, which had several occupants last year; and Terrmel Sledge is in left field in place of Roberts.
Maddux, a 333-game winner who will be 41 in two weeks, joins a pitching staff that was the league's best last season with the only earned run average under 4.00.

The Los Angeles Dodgers, who matched the Padres' record but had to settle for the wild card, have changed, too. Schmidt and Wolf join the rotation, and Luis Gonzalez and Pierre make up two-thirds of a new outfield. Pierre made the most outs in the majors last season, but he also had at least 200 hits for the fourth time in his seven-year career.

The San Francisco Giants have struggled the past two seasons, and that is why they have a bunch of new players -- Rich Aurilia at first, Roberts in center, Molina behind the plate and Zito and Russ Ortiz in the rotation.
Zito is the centerpiece of the new-look team, a pitcher who has never missed a start and has pitched more than 210 innings in each of his six full seasons.

But no matter who Zito is or how much his contract is worth, he still takes second billing to Bonds, who needs 22 home runs to become the career leader, no matter how many he might have hit with chemical aid.
The Giants should be able to compete with the Padres and the Dodgers, but the Arizona Diamondbacks and the Colorado Rockies do not appear to be in their class.

At age 43 and coming back from back surgery, Johnson may be past his prime, but the Diamondbacks badly need him to provide a spark. A spark could come, too, from shortstop Stephen Drew, the brother of J. D. who hit .316 in 59 games for Arizona last season.

The Rockies continue to bumble along, having had six successive losing seasons. They have a new center fielder, Willy Taveras, and a rookie shortstop, Troy Tulowitzki, but the same old cast will most likely produce the same old result.
MARK YOUR CALENDAR
BARRY BONDS needs 22 home runs to break Hank Aaron's career record of 755. Bonds played in 130 games last season and hit his 22nd on Sept. 4. He had 26 over all.
LOS ANGELES DODGERS 2006: 88-74, wild card

PROBABLE STARTERS 1B Nomar Garciaparra 2B Jeff Kent SS Rafael Furcal 3B Wilson Betemit LF Luis Gonzalez CF Juan Pierre RF Andre Ethier C Russell Martin SP Derek Lowe Randy Wolf Jason Schmidt Brad Penny Brett Tomko Closer Takashi Saito
